unit_learning_outcomes.description: Identify and describe behavioural patterns uncovered in behavioural economics and how they connect to standard economics outcomes and observations.
Evaluate the contribution of behavioural economics to economic knowledge.
Critique the microeconomic policy implications of typical human behaviours.
Analyse the impact of typical human behaviours on economic outcomes.

enrolment_rules.description: 50cp at 1000 level or above including ECON111 or ECON1020

assessments.description: Application of behavioural economics to a student-selected real-world problem.

Weekly sessions will involve small-group discussion and responses to the provided online material. The group outputs will be synthesised and discussed by the group as a whole. Individuals will keep a record of their own reflections on the sessions in a personal blog on iLearn.

Three times during the session a discussion forum will be opened and starting topics provided. Students will be expected to contribute to the discussions and interact with peers in sharing perspectives and information.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.description: The main aim of the unit is to provide an appreciation of how fundamental and evolving models of behaviour can help us understand issues of our contemporary world. Tools and concepts (such as supply and demand, choices and incentives, market failure, externalities, games and strategies, and behavioural economics) may be used to analyse issues of environmental damage and economic prosperity, money and happiness, cash versus gifts, art and the artist, market domination by the big brands, social networks, and more. The unit will be of interest to economics and non-economics students; the topics covered add depth to traditional introductory economics topics.
data.title: Behavioural Economics
